Simple intonation for statements (falling) and yes/no questions (rising).
listening_comprehension_skills: Recognize familiar words and very basic phrases concerning him/herself, his/her family and immediate concrete surroundings when people speak slowly and clearly.

Identify numbers, colors, and names of familiar objects when heard.
reading_comprehension_skills: Understand familiar names, words and very simple sentences, for example on notices, posters, labels, or in catalogues.
Recognize the letters of the English alphabet in print.
Match simple words with pictures.
Understand very short, simple instructions (e.g., 'Stop', 'Start').
spoken_interaction_skills: Use basic greetings and leave-taking expressions (Hello, Hi, Good morning, Good afternoon, Good evening, Goodbye, Bye).
Use basic social expressions (Thank you, Please, You're welcome, Sorry, Excuse me).
Introduce oneself and others simply ("My name is [Name].", "This is [Name].").
Ask and answer simple questions about name, age, and origin ("What's your name?", "How old are you?", "Where are you from?").
Respond to simple questions with 'yes' or 'no'.
Make very simple requests (e.g., "A coffee, please.").
spoken_production_skills: Use simple phrases and sentences to name familiar people and objects.
State one's name, age, and country of origin.
Count from 1 to 20.
Name basic colors.
Produce simple isolated phrases and very basic sentences about oneself and immediate surroundings.
written_interaction_skills: Respond to simple written prompts with single words or short phrases (e.g., filling in name on a list).
written_production_skills: Write the letters of the English alphabet (uppercase and lowercase).
Write one's own name, age, and nationality.
Copy familiar words and short simple sentences.
Fill in a very simple form with personal details (name, nationality, date of birth - basic).
cultural_competence_topics: Common greeting gestures (e.g., handshake, wave).
Basic forms of address (Mr., Mrs., Miss - though Ms. is often preferred for women).
Awareness of some English-speaking countries and their flags.
Understanding that 'please' and 'thank you' are very important.
learning_strategies_suggestions: Practice the alphabet and sounds daily using charts or apps.
Use flashcards with pictures for new vocabulary (objects, colors, numbers).
Listen to and repeat simple English songs or nursery rhymes.
Label common household items in English.

learning_outcomes: Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type related to personal life, daily routines, and immediate environment.
Can introduce oneself and others in more detail, ask and answer questions about personal details (residence, possessions, acquaintances, simple likes/dislikes).
Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help, on familiar topics.
Can understand short, simple written texts on familiar topics, such as simple descriptions or personal messages.
Can write short, simple notes and messages.

Object pronouns (me, you, him, her, it, us, them).
Possessive 's (John's book) and possessive pronouns (mine, yours, his, hers).

Present Simple tense â€“ positive, negative, questions (with do/does) for routines and facts.

Demonstratives: this/that/these/those (expanded use).
Question words: what, where, who, how many, how old, when, why (simple questions).
There is/There are (positive, negative, question forms with some/any).
Prepositions of place (in, on, under, next to, behind, in front of, between).
Prepositions of time (at (time), on (days), in (months, seasons, years) - basic).
Modal verb 'can/can't' (for ability and permission - simple).
Verbs 'like', 'love', 'hate' + -ing or noun.
Imperatives (positive and negative for simple instructions).
Past Simple tense (verb 'to be': was/were).

Family & Relatives (expanded: e.g., aunt, uncle, cousin, grandparents, husband, wife, son, daughter, children).
Jobs (common ones: teacher, doctor, student, driver, shop assistant, nurse, police officer, waiter/waitress, farmer).
Personal information (address, phone number, email address - understanding and giving simply, date of birth).
Adjectives (describing objects, people, places, feelings â€“ more variety e.g., beautiful, old, new, long, short, tall, tasty, cheap, expensive, tired, hungry, thirsty, cold, hot).

Daily routines & Free time activities (common ones: get up, have breakfast/lunch/dinner, go to school/work/bed, do homework, watch TV, listen to music, play games/sports, read, swim, dance, cook, meet friends, go shopping).
Food & Drink (common items: apple, banana, orange, bread, milk, water, coffee, tea, rice, chicken, fish, meat, vegetables, fruit, juice, cheese, eggs, sandwich, cake, chocolate).
Verb + noun collocations (have breakfast/lunch/dinner, go to school/work/bed, do homework, watch TV, listen to music, play football/tennis, take a photo).
Rooms in a house & Furniture (living room, kitchen, bedroom, bathroom; table, chair, bed, sofa, TV, lamp, window, door, cupboard, shower, toilet).
Places in a city/village (shop, school, park, supermarket, station, hospital, post office, bank, cafe, restaurant, cinema, library, museum, beach, market).
Clothing (shirt, trousers, dress, shoes, T-shirt, sweater/jumper, coat, hat, socks, skirt, shorts, jacket, scarf, gloves).
Transport & Travel (car, bus, train, bike, plane, boat, taxi, walk, ticket, station, airport, hotel).
Days of the week, Months of the year, Seasons (spring, summer, autumn/fall, winter).

Ordinal numbers (1st to 31st for dates).
pronunciation_focus_topics: Pronunciation of regular past simple -ed endings (/d/, /t/, /Éªd/).
Common vowel sounds (short vs. long, e.g., ship/sheep, bit/beat, pull/pool).
Common consonant sounds, including digraphs (e.g., sh /Êƒ/, ch /tÊƒ/, th /Î¸/, /Ã°/, ng /Å‹/).
Word stress in two-syllable words with common patterns (e.g., 'OBject' vs 'obJECT').

Intonation in Wh- questions (usually falling) and yes/no questions (rising).
Silent letters in common words (e.g., 'know', 'write').
listening_comprehension_skills: Understand familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases related to personal details, family, shopping, local area, employment, when people speak slowly and clearly.
Identify key information (e.g., names, numbers, times, places, prices) in short, clear, simple messages, announcements, and dialogues on familiar topics.
Understand simple directions on how to get from one place to another (e.g., 'turn left', 'go straight').
Follow short, simple dialogues about familiar topics (e.g., ordering food, making a simple purchase, asking for basic information).
reading_comprehension_skills: Understand short, simple texts on familiar matters (e.g., simple descriptions of people or places, advertisements for common products, short personal messages/emails, simple menus, basic instructions).
Find specific, predictable information in simple everyday material such as advertisements, prospectuses, menus, timetables, and event posters.
Understand short simple personal letters or emails from friends or family about familiar topics like hobbies, daily routines, or recent activities.
Follow a sequence of simple instructions for everyday tasks (e.g., a very simple recipe, instructions for a game).
spoken_interaction_skills: Ask and answer questions about daily routines, likes/dislikes, abilities (can/can't), and simple past events.
Tell the time (o'clock, half past, quarter past/to) and discuss schedules.
Talk about days, dates, and simple past events with others.
Make simple purchases in shops (asking for items, price, size, expressing what one wants).
Order food and drink in a cafÃ© or restaurant and make simple requests (e.g., "I'd like...", "Can I have the bill, please?", asking about ingredients simply).
Ask for and give simple directions to a place within a familiar area.
Make and respond to simple suggestions or invitations (e.g., "Let's go...", "Would you like to...?", accepting/declining politely).
Use the phone for very simple interactions (e.g., making a simple inquiry, leaving a very brief message if prompted).
spoken_production_skills: Describe one's family, friends, living conditions, educational background, and present or most recent job in a series of simple phrases and sentences.
Talk about daily routines, habits, and preferences using Present Simple and adverbs of frequency.
Express likes and dislikes simply (e.g., "I like apples." "I don't like spiders.").
Describe simple plans for the immediate future (e.g., Present Continuous for future: "I'm meeting John tomorrow."; 'going to' for intentions).
Talk about past activities and experiences in a simple way using Past Simple (e.g., "Yesterday I went to the park and played football.").
Describe abilities using 'can' and 'can't' (e.g., "I can swim, but I can't ski.").
written_interaction_skills: Write short, simple postcards, emails, or text messages to friends or family (e.g., holiday greetings, thank you notes, making simple arrangements, giving brief news).
Reply to simple written questions or messages from others about familiar topics, providing requested information.
Fill in a simple online form with personal details or for a basic request.
written_production_skills: Write short, simple notes and messages relating to matters in areas of immediate need or familiar topics (e.g., a shopping list, a reminder note to oneself, a short note to a family member).
Describe a person, place, object, or a simple event in a few connected sentences, using basic descriptive adjectives.
Write simple sentences and short paragraphs about daily routines, preferences, or past activities, using basic conjunctions (and, but, so, because).
Fill in simple forms requiring personal details (name, address, nationality, date of birth, phone number).
cultural_competence_topics: Common English foods and mealtime customs (e.g., typical breakfast, lunch, dinner; concept of 'packed lunch').
Basic etiquette in shops, restaurants, and when using public transport in English-speaking environments.
Awareness of major holidays in English-speaking countries (e.g., Christmas, Easter, Thanksgiving (US), Halloween) and some common associated traditions or symbols.
Understanding of common units of measurement (e.g., pounds/kilos for weight, miles/kilometers for distance, common currency names like pound, dollar, euro - basic recognition and use).
Politeness in requests and offers (e.g., using 'please', 'thank you', 'excuse me').
Common ways of addressing people (first name vs. title + last name in different situations).
learning_strategies_suggestions: Label more objects in English in your home and workplace/study area, including actions or states.
Practice speaking English with a language partner, tutor, or in a group regularly, trying to use new vocabulary and grammar.
Watch short English cartoons, simple vlogs, or educational videos designed for learners, with or without English subtitles, focusing on comprehension.
Start a simple diary or journal in English, writing a few connected sentences each day about your activities, feelings, or plans.
Use a bilingual dictionary to look up new words and try to make sentences with them; start using a simple learner's monolingual dictionary.
Review new vocabulary and grammar points regularly using flashcards, apps, or by rewriting notes.
Try to guess the meaning of unknown words from context in simple texts.

learning_outcomes: Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment).
Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters.
Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need.
language_focus_topics: Review of A1: Verb 'to be' (present & past), 'have got', Present Simple, Past Simple (common regular & irregular verbs), can/can't, articles, possessives, demonstratives, basic prepositions.
Present Continuous (for actions happening now, future arrangements - consolidation and expansion).
Past Continuous (for background actions, interrupted actions in the past - e.g., I was watching TV when the phone rang).
'Going to' future (for plans and predictions - consolidation).
Present Perfect Simple (with ever, never, yet, just, already, for/since - for experiences and recent past actions with present relevance).
Comparative and superlative adjectives (regular: -er/-est, more/most; common irregulars: good, bad, far).
Adverbs of manner (e.g., slowly, carefully, well), frequency (consolidation), time, and place.
Quantifiers (some, any, much, many, a lot of, (a) few, (a) little).
Countable and uncountable nouns (basic understanding and use with quantifiers).
Modal verbs: could (past ability, polite requests), should/shouldn't (advice), must/mustn't (obligation/prohibition), may/might (possibility).
Infinitive of purpose (e.g., I went to the shop to buy bread).
Question tags (simple, for confirmation - e.g., It's nice, isn't it?).
Conjunctions: and, but, or, so, because, when, if (zero and first conditional review), before, after, while.
Basic phrasal verbs (e.g., get up, turn on/off, look for).
vocabulary_topics: Personal information (expanded: date/place of birth, marital status - simple, contact details).
Family & relationships (describing family members and simple relationships in more detail).
Jobs & professions (wider range, describing responsibilities simply).
Daily routines & free time activities (describing a typical day, hobbies, sports, interests with more specific vocabulary).
Housing & furniture (types of houses/flats, more specific furniture, basic appliances, describing one's home).
Food & drink (wider range of food items, ingredients, types of meals, cooking verbs - basic, ordering in a restaurant with more options).
Shopping (types of shops, clothes and accessories - materials, sizes, asking for help, making simple complaints, payment methods).
Town & country (places in town, countryside features, giving and understanding more detailed directions).
Describing people (physical appearance: height, build, hair style/color, eye color; personality traits: kind, friendly, funny, shy, serious, talkative).
Feelings & emotions (happy, sad, angry, tired, bored, excited, worried, surprised, interested).
The weather (describing current weather and simple forecasts).
Travel & transport (types of transport, travel items, booking tickets, airport/station vocabulary, asking for travel information, simple problems).
Health & body (common ailments and symptoms, parts of the body, visiting a doctor/dentist/pharmacy).
Education (school subjects, timetable, simple descriptions of school life and studies).
pronunciation_focus_topics: Common problematic vowel sounds and diphthongs (e.g., /eÉª/ as in 'say', /aÉª/ as in 'my', /É”Éª/ as in 'boy').
Common problematic consonant clusters (e.g., 'str-', 'thr-').
Word stress in longer words (3+ syllables) with common patterns.
Sentence stress and rhythm in longer sentences, identifying stressed and unstressed syllables.
Intonation for different types of questions (yes/no, Wh-, tag questions) and expressing basic emotions (surprise, interest).
Linking sounds more consistently in connected speech (e.g., consonant to vowel linking).
listening_comprehension_skills: Understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g., personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment).
Identify the main point and key details in short, clear, simple messages, announcements, and straightforward dialogues on familiar topics.
Understand simple instructions and directions when spoken clearly and at a moderate pace.
Follow short, simple narratives about everyday events or familiar stories.
Recognize speaker's basic attitude or emotion (e.g., happiness, sadness, surprise) in simple exchanges.
reading_comprehension_skills: Understand short, simple texts (e.g., personal letters/emails, simple articles on familiar topics, instructions, short stories for learners) containing high-frequency vocabulary.
Find specific, predictable information in everyday material such as advertisements, brochures, menus, timetables, and short official documents.
Understand the main idea and some supporting details in simple narratives or descriptive texts.
Follow a sequence of instructions for a familiar task or process.
Infer the meaning of some unknown words from context if the topic is familiar.
spoken_interaction_skills: Communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters.
Engage in short social exchanges (e.g., greeting, asking how someone is, reacting to news, making simple arrangements to meet).
Handle simple transactions in shops, post offices, or banks; order food, ask for services, and make simple complaints.
Discuss past events, experiences, and future plans simply.
Make and respond to suggestions, invitations, and apologies with reasons.
Ask for and give directions or information about places, using prepositions and common landmarks.
Express basic opinions, preferences, agreement/disagreement with simple justifications.
spoken_production_skills: Describe oneâ€™s family, other people, living conditions, educational background, and present or most recent job using a series of simple connected sentences.
Give short, basic descriptions of events, activities, and personal experiences (past, present, and future plans), linking ideas with basic connectors.
Describe habits, routines, and what one likes or dislikes about something, providing simple reasons.
Compare two people or things in a simple way (e.g., "This car is bigger than that one.").
Retell a short story or the plot of a film/book in simple terms.
written_interaction_skills: Write short, simple notes, messages, emails, or social media posts related to everyday situations and familiar topics.
Respond to simple written questions or requests for information with relevant details in short, connected texts.
Make simple written arrangements or confirm plans (e.g., for a meeting or outing).
written_production_skills: Write a series of simple phrases and sentences linked with basic connectors (and, but, because, so, then, after, before) to describe experiences, events, or feelings.
Write a short, simple personal letter, email, or blog post describing an event, a trip, personal impressions, or future plans.
Write a simple description of a person, place, familiar object, or daily routine.
Fill in forms requiring more detailed personal information (e.g., simple application forms).
cultural_competence_topics: Understanding common customs related to hospitality, invitations, gift-giving, and punctuality in English-speaking cultures.
Awareness of appropriate topics for small talk and topics to avoid in initial conversations.
Recognizing differences in politeness conventions (e.g., use of 'please', 'thank you', forms of address for strangers vs. acquaintances).
Familiarity with some famous landmarks, cultural icons, or traditions from major English-speaking countries (e.g., specific holidays, types of food, popular sports).
Basic understanding of how public services work (e.g., post office, public transport).
Awareness of non-verbal communication cues (e.g., eye contact, personal space - basic).
learning_strategies_suggestions: Try to use new vocabulary and grammar in short conversations or written messages, focusing on connecting ideas.
Use a monolingual learner's dictionary for English to understand definitions and see more examples of usage.
Practice writing short paragraphs or simple stories about familiar topics, and ask for feedback if possible.
Watch English videos or TV programs suitable for learners, with English subtitles, and try to summarize what happened.
Set specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) goals for language learning.
Review Past Simple irregular verbs regularly.
Pay attention to collocations (words that often go together).

learning_outcomes: Can understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc.
Can deal with most situations likely to arise whilst travelling in an area where the language is spoken.
Can produce simple connected text on topics, which are familiar, or of personal interest.
Can describe experiences and events, dreams, hopes & ambitions and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans.
language_focus_topics: Review of A2 tenses: Present Simple, Present Continuous, Past Simple, Present Perfect, 'going to' future.
Past Continuous (for background actions, interrupted actions, simultaneous past actions).
Past Perfect Simple (for sequencing past events, before another past event).
Future Simple (will - for predictions, spontaneous decisions, offers, promises).
Future Continuous (for actions in progress at a specific future time).
Future Perfect Simple (for actions completed by a specific future time).
Verb patterns: verb + infinitive (e.g., want to, decide to), verb + -ing (e.g., enjoy doing, stop doing), verb + preposition + -ing (e.g., interested in doing).
Comparatives & superlatives (regular and irregular adjectives and adverbs, as...as, less...than, not as...as).

Modals: have to/don't have to (obligation/lack of obligation), should/shouldn't (advice), must/mustn't (strong obligation/prohibition), might/may (possibility), could (past ability, polite requests, possibility).

Conditionals: Zero (general truths), First (real future possibilities: if + Present Simple, ... will + infinitive), Second (hypothetical present/future situations: if + Past Simple, ... would + infinitive).
Passive voice (Present Simple and Past Simple passives).
Reported speech: simple statements, questions, and commands (tense shifts, pronoun changes).
Relative clauses: defining clauses with who, which, that, whose, where, when (omission of relative pronoun as object).

Conjunctions and linking words (time: when, while, as soon as, before, after, until; reason: because, as, so; contrast: but, although, however, despite, in spite of; purpose: to, in order to, so that).
vocabulary_topics: Work and study: Job descriptions, job interviews, applying for jobs/courses, school/university life, subjects, exams, future career plans.
Travel and tourism: Planning trips, booking accommodation and transport, sightseeing, describing travel experiences, common problems during travel and solutions, types of holidays.
Hobbies and interests: Describing them in more detail, equipment needed, expressing enthusiasm or preferences, joining clubs, discussing rules of games/sports.
Personal relationships: Friendships, family dynamics, describing character and personality traits (e.g., reliable, honest, selfish, kind), expressing feelings about relationships, stages of life.
Food and culture: Regional cuisines, national dishes, traditions, festivals, eating habits, discussing recipes, ingredients, cooking methods.
Health and lifestyle: Fitness, diet, healthy habits, common illnesses and treatments, giving simple advice on health, describing symptoms in more detail.
Current events and news: Understanding main points of newspaper/online articles on familiar topics, discussing current topics simply, expressing opinions.
Environment: Basic environmental issues (pollution, recycling, climate change), expressing concerns, simple solutions.
Expressing opinions, agreement, disagreement: Structuring simple arguments, giving reasons, polite disagreement.
Feelings and emotions: Expressing a wider range of feelings (joy, sadness, anger, fear, surprise, hope, disappointment, excitement, boredom, worry) with more nuance.
Technology and communication: Basic terms related to computers, internet, mobile phones, social media, email.
Narrative: Describing past events in sequence, telling simple stories with more detail.
Films, books, music: Discussing plots, characters, preferences, simple reviews.
Describing appearance and personality in more detail.
pronunciation_focus_topics: Stress and intonation in longer sentences, including compound and complex sentences with multiple clauses.
Intonation patterns for different communicative functions (e.g., expressing surprise, doubt, agreement, disagreement, giving advice, making polite requests).
Connected speech: common assimilations, elisions, and linking /r/ to improve fluency and naturalness; weak forms of auxiliary verbs and prepositions.
Pronunciation of challenging consonant clusters and vowel sounds with greater accuracy.
Word stress in polysyllabic words, including common suffixes that affect stress (e.g., -tion, -ity, -graphy).
Rhythm in English speech, focusing on stress-timed patterns and appropriate pausing for clarity.
listening_comprehension_skills: Understand the main points of clear standard speech on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc., including short narratives, announcements, and straightforward factual accounts.
Understand the main points of many radio or TV programmes on current affairs or topics of personal or professional interest when the delivery is relatively slow and clear.
Follow the general outline of lectures, talks, or presentations on familiar topics if clearly structured.
Understand instructions or directions related to work, study, or travel, including multi-step instructions.
Identify the speaker's mood, attitude, and opinion in clear, standard speech on familiar topics.
reading_comprehension_skills: Understand texts that consist mainly of high frequency everyday or job-related language, and the description of events, feelings, and wishes in personal letters, emails, and straightforward articles.
Scan longer texts in order to locate desired information, and gather information from different parts of a text, or from different texts in order to fulfil a specific task.
Recognise significant points and main arguments in straightforward newspaper or magazine articles on familiar subjects, and identify the writer's general stance.
Understand simple instructions for equipment, procedures, or recipes.
Follow the plot of a simple story, narrative, or film review, understanding the sequence of events and main characters' motivations.
spoken_interaction_skills: Enter unprepared into conversation on topics that are familiar, of personal interest or pertinent to everyday life (e.g. family, hobbies, work, travel and current events), and sustain the conversation.

Deal with most situations likely to arise whilst travelling in an area where the language is spoken (e.g., making travel arrangements, checking into a hotel, asking for help or information, dealing with minor problems or complaints).
Express and ask for personal opinions, beliefs, and ideas in familiar contexts, and respond to those of others by agreeing, disagreeing politely, and giving reasons.
Narrate a story or relate the plot of a book or film, describe reactions, and exchange views.
Clarify points, ask for clarification when necessary, and check understanding.
Make and respond to suggestions, advice, and invitations, negotiating details.
spoken_production_skills: Produce simple connected text on a range of familiar subjects or topics of personal interest, linking ideas into a coherent sequence.
Briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions, plans, and actions.
Narrate a story, or describe an event or personal experience, including feelings and reactions, with some detail.
Describe dreams, hopes, and ambitions, and explain future plans.
Relate the plot of a book or film and describe personal reactions and opinions, giving examples.
Give a straightforward, prepared presentation on a familiar topic within their field, explaining main points with reasonable precision and supporting them with some details.
written_interaction_skills: Write personal letters, emails, or online messages describing experiences, feelings, and events in some detail, and commenting on the correspondent's news and views.
Exchange information in writing on familiar routine and non-routine matters within their field with some confidence (e.g., requesting information, making arrangements, confirming details).
Make notes while someone is talking or during a presentation on familiar topics, summarizing key points and questions for follow-up.
Contribute to online forums or group discussions on familiar topics, expressing opinions and responding to others.
written_production_skills: Write simple connected text on a range of familiar subjects or subjects of personal interest, linking a series of shorter discrete elements into a linear and coherent sequence using appropriate conjunctions.
Write personal letters, emails, or short blog posts describing experiences, events, feelings, and impressions in some detail.
Write a short, simple essay or report on a topic of interest, providing reasons for their views, structuring ideas logically with an introduction, body, and conclusion.
Describe the plot of a book or film, or a personal experience, in writing, including personal reactions.
Take messages containing simple factual information and convey them accurately to a third party.
cultural_competence_topics: Understanding common social etiquette and conventions in various situations in English-speaking cultures (e.g., formal vs. informal address, making requests, apologies, compliments).
Awareness of some important historical and cultural figures, events, and symbols in major English-speaking countries and their general significance.
Understanding common English proverbs, sayings, or idioms and their general meaning in context.
Introduction to different regional accents within major English-speaking countries (e.g., basic differences between British and American English pronunciation).
Basic understanding of common values, attitudes, and social norms (e.g., regarding punctuality, personal space, directness in communication).
Recognizing humor and irony in simple, clear contexts.
Understanding how to navigate public services and common everyday situations (e.g., using public transport, shopping, eating out).
learning_strategies_suggestions: Read graded readers or simple authentic English articles, blogs, or short stories regularly, trying to guess the meaning of unknown words from context before using a dictionary.
Watch English TV shows, interviews, or movies with English subtitles, paying attention to colloquial language, expressions, and how ideas are linked.
Practice writing longer texts like emails detailing plans, diary entries about experiences, or short opinion pieces on familiar topics, focusing on connecting ideas coherently.
Set specific language learning goals (e.g., learn 5 new phrasal verbs related to travel this week, practice using conditional sentences in conversation) and track progress.
Use monolingual learner's dictionaries to understand nuances of meaning, see collocations, and check example sentences.
Actively look for opportunities to use English in real-life situations or online forums for topics of interest.
Practice summarizing short texts or talks in your own words.
Pay attention to how native speakers structure their arguments or tell stories.

learning_outcomes: Can understand the main ideas of complex text on both concrete and abstract topics, including technical discussions in his/her field of specialisation.
Can interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity that makes regular interaction with native speakers quite possible without strain for either party.
Can produce clear, detailed text on a wide range of subjects and explain a viewpoint on a topical issue giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options.
language_focus_topics: Review of the tense system (comprehensive understanding and application of all tenses, including perfect and continuous aspects).
Question forms, Negatives & Short Answers (complex questions, tag questions, indirect questions, nuanced negative structures).
Simple & Continuous (Present Tenses â€“ active and passive, including stative verbs and their continuous forms where appropriate)
Simple & Continuous (Past Tenses â€“ active and passive, including narrative tenses and their interplay)
Past Perfect (review and more complex uses, e.g., with reporting verbs, in unreal past conditionals)
used to / would (for past habits and states, distinction between them)
Modals & related verbs (advice, obligation & permission - review and expansion: e.g., ought to, be allowed to, be supposed to, had better)
Future forms (will, going to, Present Continuous, Future Continuous, Future Perfect - distinctions and appropriate use)
Future possibilities (modals for future speculation: may, might, could, will probably)
Information questions (embedded questions, reported questions)

Verb Patterns (expanded: verb + object + to-infinitive, verb + gerund/infinitive with change in meaning, causative have/get)

Modals of Probability (present and past: must be/have been, can't be/have been, may/might/could be/have been)

Double genitive with possessive pronoun + 's (e.g., a friend of mine's house)
vocabulary_topics: Positive & negative adjectives (wider range, nuanced meanings, prefixes/suffixes for forming opposites)
Free time activities (more specific and niche hobbies, expressing preferences and opinions about them)
Phrasal Verbs (1) literal vs idiomatic, separable vs inseparable (systematic study and expansion)
Word transformations (forming different parts of speech from a root word, e.g., beauty -> beautiful -> beautifully)
Describing people & things (more detailed and nuanced descriptions of appearance, personality, characteristics, qualities)
Adjectives / Adverbs (wider range, collocations, intensifying adverbs, adverbial phrases)
Describing likes & dislikes (more sophisticated ways to express preferences, indifference, aversion)
Idioms (common idioms, especially those related to parts of the body, understanding figurative language)
Words with a similar meaning (synonyms for more precise expression, register differences)
Compound nouns (expanded range, understanding formation and stress patterns)
Phrasal Verbs (2) common phrasal verbs with out / up (e.g., work out, find out, give up, set up)
Reporting Verbs (e.g., suggest, recommend, warn, promise, admit, deny - beyond say/tell)
Noun phrases (complex noun phrases, use of articles, determiners, quantifiers, pre/post-modification)
pronunciation_focus_topics: Fine-tuning intonation to convey subtle meanings, attitudes, and emotions (e.g., irony, doubt, enthusiasm, sarcasm, politeness).
Achieving fluency and natural rhythm in extended speech, including appropriate pausing, phrasing, and chunking of information.
Understanding and using features of connected speech typical of educated native speakers (e.g., more complex assimilations, elisions, reductions, linking).
Stress patterns in longer and more complex words, including compound words and words with common prefixes/suffixes.
Sentence stress for emphasis and contrast.
Recognizing and dealing with variations in common native speaker accents (e.g., General American, British RP - basic awareness).
listening_comprehension_skills: Understand extended speech and lectures, and follow even complex lines of argument provided the topic is reasonably familiar.
Understand most TV news, current affairs programmes, documentaries, and interviews.
Understand the majority of films, plays, and radio broadcasts in standard dialect, including implicit meanings and attitudes.
Follow conversations between native speakers on a variety of general and more specialized topics, even in slightly noisy environments.
Identify speaker's viewpoint, opinion, and purpose in spoken discourse.
reading_comprehension_skills: Read articles and reports concerned with contemporary problems in which the writers adopt particular stances or viewpoints, understanding both explicit and implicit information.
Understand contemporary literary prose and appreciate stylistic choices.
Understand specialized articles and technical texts related to own field or areas of interest, and some outside these areas with occasional use of a dictionary.
Identify writer's purpose, tone, bias, and intended audience in various types of texts.
Distinguish fact from opinion in news articles and argumentative texts.
Summarize the main points of complex texts.

Giving opinions (structuring opinions, supporting them with reasons, agreeing/disagreeing politely but firmly)
Polite requests & offers (using more indirect and formal language where appropriate)
Arranging to meet (negotiating times and places, confirming arrangements, handling changes)
Shopping (handling more complex transactions, inquiries about products, discussing problems, understanding policies)
Responding appropriately (agreement, sympathy, pleasure, surprise - using a wider range of expressions and showing nuance)
Travel, number & money (discussing detailed travel plans, understanding complex information about schedules/prices, handling currency exchange and payments confidently)
Describing in detail (providing rich descriptions of people, places, objects, events, experiences)
Expressing attitude (conveying feelings and opinions through intonation, word choice, and idiomatic language)
ClichÃ©s and comments (understanding and using common clichÃ©s and conversational fillers appropriately)
Metaphors & Idioms (understanding and using common metaphors and idioms in context)
Linking & Commenting (using discourse markers to structure speech, connect ideas, and add comments)
spoken_production_skills: Exchanging information (confidently on a wide range of familiar and unfamiliar topics, handling abstract concepts)
Talking about you (life, plans, feelings, concerns - with more depth, detail, and nuance)
Recounting a story / play (detailed and engaging recounting, using appropriate narrative techniques)
Giving opinions to real situations (analyzing situations, expressing well-reasoned opinions, speculating)
Describing environmental issues (discussing causes, effects, and potential solutions related to the environment)
Interviewing someone (preparing and asking appropriate questions, responding to answers, managing the interaction)
Describing famous people & situations (providing detailed descriptions and discussing their significance)
written_interaction_skills: Write clear, detailed emails, letters, or messages on a variety of complex subjects, adapting style, tone, and register to the recipient and purpose.
Exchange, check, and confirm detailed information effectively, explain a problem in detail, make a formal complaint or request, and express thanks or appreciation appropriately.

Participate actively in online discussions, forums, or collaborative documents on familiar and some unfamiliar topics, expressing views clearly, supporting them with arguments, and responding thoughtfully to others' contributions.
written_production_skills: Informal & Formal letters & emails (distinguishing register, appropriate tone and structure for various purposes)
Narratives (more complex stories with developed plot, characters, and atmosphere)
Writing a Biography (well-structured, detailed, and engaging biographies)
Describing places & people (vivid and detailed descriptions, appealing to senses, using a rich vocabulary)
Writing for talking (presentations - structuring content logically, using signposting language, preparing visuals)
Arguments (Pros & Cons - developing arguments, providing evidence, structuring essays or reports)
Expressing attitude (linking ideas - using cohesive devices, discourse markers, and appropriate vocabulary to convey stance and connect arguments)
cultural_competence_topics: Deeper understanding of cultural norms, values, and attitudes in major English-speaking societies (e.g., regarding work ethic, social interaction, education, family).
Nuances of formal and informal communication, politeness strategies, and directness/indirectness in different English-speaking cultures.
Understanding common cultural references, allusions, and humor in English media, literature, and everyday conversation.
Awareness of different social and regional varieties of English and their general characteristics (e.g., British vs. American English differences in vocabulary and pronunciation).
Understanding of contemporary social and political issues in English-speaking countries and how they are discussed.
Appreciation of different perspectives and cultural assumptions.
learning_strategies_suggestions: Read a variety of authentic English texts regularly (news, articles, fiction, non-fiction) from different sources.
Watch English-language films, documentaries, and TV series without subtitles, or with English subtitles for detailed understanding and vocabulary acquisition.
Engage in discussions and debates in English on more complex or abstract topics, focusing on argumentation and fluency.
Write different types of texts (essays, reports, reviews, formal letters) regularly, paying attention to structure, cohesion, register, and accuracy.
Seek feedback on written and spoken English from native speakers, advanced learners, or teachers, and act on it.
Actively expand vocabulary by noting down new words and expressions with their context, collocations, and nuances of meaning. Use a good monolingual dictionary.
Practice summarizing information from different sources and presenting it in your own words.
Develop critical thinking skills when engaging with English-language media.

learning_outcomes: Can understand a wide range of demanding, longer texts, and recognise implicit meaning.
Can express him/herself fluently and spontaneously without much obvious searching for expressions.
Can use language flexibly and effectively for social, academic and professional purposes.
Can produce clear, well-structured, detailed text on complex subjects, showing controlled use of organisational patterns, connectors and cohesive devices.
language_focus_topics: Mastery of the English tense system (simple, continuous, perfect aspects - active & passive), including subtle nuances for emphasis, aspect, and time relations.
Advanced modal usage (speculation, deduction, criticism, regret, degrees of certainty/possibility in past, present, future). Complex modal-like expressions.
Conditionals (all types, including mixed conditionals, inverted conditionals, hypothetical structures with 'wish', 'if only', 'would rather', 'it's time').
Advanced passive constructions (e.g., with reporting verbs, 'have something done', impersonal passives, passives with infinitives and gerunds).

Complex sentence structures: subordination and coordination, advanced use of relative clauses (non-defining, reduced, with prepositions), participle clauses (dangling/misrelated participles to avoid), nominal clauses (that-clauses, wh-clauses, infinitive/gerund clauses as subject/object).
Emphasis and focus structures (cleft sentences, inversion after negative/limiting adverbials, fronting).
Nuances of articles, determiners, and quantifiers in complex noun phrases.
Figurative language: understanding and using metaphors, similes, idioms, proverbs, collocations effectively.
Stylistic variations: adapting grammar and syntax to different genres and registers (formal, informal, academic, journalistic, literary).
Advanced discourse markers and cohesive devices for structuring complex arguments, ensuring sophisticated cohesion and coherence.
Word formation: productive use of a wide range of prefixes, suffixes, and compounding to understand and form new words, including neologisms.
Subtleties of English punctuation for clarity and style.
vocabulary_topics: Specialized vocabulary related to one's field of study, profession, or specific areas of deep interest.
Abstract and philosophical concepts, terminology for discussing complex ideas, theories, and ideologies.
Nuances of meaning between synonyms, near-synonyms, and antonyms; choosing precise and effective vocabulary for specific contexts and effects.
Low-frequency idioms, colloquial expressions, and culturally-specific sayings.
Formal, literary, and archaic vocabulary (recognition and appropriate use for stylistic effect).
Understanding and using wordplay, humor, irony, sarcasm, and understatement effectively.
Cultural, historical, and literary references and allusions embedded in language.
Terminology related to linguistics, rhetoric, critical analysis, and argumentation.
Collocations (verb-noun, adjective-noun, adverb-adjective, verb-preposition) for natural and idiomatic expression.
Euphemisms and dysphemisms.
Connotations and semantic fields of words.
pronunciation_focus_topics: Mastery of intonation, stress (word and sentence), and rhythm to convey complex attitudes, emotions, and subtle shades of meaning (e.g., enthusiasm, doubt, conviction, irony, politeness).
Near-native fluency and clarity in pronunciation across various speech styles (formal presentations, informal conversations, debates).
Effective use of prosodic features (pitch, volume, tempo) for structuring discourse, highlighting key information, and engaging the listener.
Understanding and adapting to a wider range of native speaker accents and regional variations, identifying key phonological differences.
Consistent and accurate pronunciation of complex words and low-frequency vocabulary.
Fine-tuning of individual sounds and sound clusters that may still pose challenges, achieving near-native articulation.
listening_comprehension_skills: Understand extended speech even when it is not clearly structured and when relationships are only implied and not signalled explicitly (e.g., lectures, complex presentations, academic discussions).

Understand a wide range of television programmes, films, podcasts, and radio broadcasts without too much effort, including those with colloquial language, rapid speech, or unfamiliar accents (after some acclimatization).

Follow complex interactions between third parties in group discussions, debates, and formal meetings, even on abstract, complex, and unfamiliar topics, identifying viewpoints, nuances, and implicit meanings.
Recognize and interpret a wide range of idiomatic expressions, colloquialisms, and cultural allusions, appreciating register shifts and speaker intent.
Distinguish finer shades of meaning due to prosodic features (intonation, stress, rhythm, tone of voice).
reading_comprehension_skills: Understand in detail long and complex factual, argumentative, and literary texts from a variety of genres, appreciating distinctions of style, register, and implicit meaning.

Understand specialised articles, abstract theoretical texts, academic papers, and longer technical instructions, even when they do not relate directly to own field, using contextual clues and reference materials effectively.
Critically evaluate complex texts for argumentation, evidence, bias, underlying assumptions, rhetorical strategies, and stylistic effectiveness, identifying logical fallacies or weaknesses.
Read contemporary and classical English literature with a high level of comprehension, appreciation for literary devices, and understanding of cultural/historical context.
Synthesize information and arguments from multiple complex texts to form a coherent and critical understanding of a topic.
spoken_interaction_skills: Express oneself fluently, spontaneously, and almost effortlessly, selecting precise phrasing from a readily available range of discourse items to preface remarks, gain time, and keep the turn whilst formulating what to say.

Use language flexibly and effectively for social, academic, and professional purposes, adapting style, register, and tone appropriately and subtly to the situation, participants, and communicative goals.
Formulate ideas and opinions with precision, articulate complex arguments persuasively, and relate contributions skilfully to those of other speakers in discussions, debates, and negotiations.
Participate effectively, confidently, and appropriately in formal meetings, academic seminars, professional presentations, and challenging interviews, contributing to productive outcomes.
Handle interruptions, manage turn-taking, guide conversations smoothly, and mediate effectively in discussions if necessary, demonstrating strong interpersonal skills.
Use humor, irony, understatement, and other rhetorical devices effectively and appropriately in conversation to achieve specific effects.
spoken_production_skills: Present clear, detailed, well-structured descriptions or arguments on complex subjects, integrating sub-themes, developing particular points at length with well-chosen supporting evidence and examples, and rounding off with an appropriate and memorable conclusion in a well-structured and engaging manner.
Deliver well-structured, engaging, and persuasive presentations on complex or abstract topics to diverse audiences, adapting style, content, and delivery effectively to suit the context.
Argue a complex case effectively, persuasively, and with nuance, using appropriate evidence, logical reasoning, and sophisticated rhetorical strategies to convince an audience.
Speak with a high degree of grammatical accuracy, using a wide and varied range of complex sentence structures and sophisticated vocabulary precisely, idiomatically, and naturally.
Vary intonation and place sentence stress correctly and effectively in order to express finer shades of meaning and attitudes.
written_interaction_skills: Write clear, well-structured, and stylistically sophisticated emails, letters, reports, and other documents on complex subjects for various professional, academic, or personal purposes and audiences, adapting tone and register flawlessly.
Respond effectively, persuasively, and with nuance to complex written communications, addressing all points raised comprehensively and anticipating potential follow-up questions or concerns.

Contribute effectively and authoritatively to professional or academic correspondence, collaborative writing projects, and formal written discussions, demonstrating a strong command of the subject matter and linguistic resources.
written_production_skills: Write clear, well-structured, and detailed text on complex subjects, showing controlled and sophisticated use of organisational patterns, a wide range of connectors, and cohesive devices to produce coherent, engaging, and stylistically accomplished discourse.

Write clear, detailed, well-structured and persuasive reports, academic essays, articles, or research papers on complex subjects, underlining the relevant salient issues, presenting a well-reasoned and nuanced argument, synthesizing information from multiple sources critically, and citing appropriately according to academic conventions.

Write different kinds of texts (e.g., critical reviews of literature or art, summaries of complex information, critiques of arguments, detailed proposals for projects) in an appropriate, effective, and often elegant style, adapting content, structure, and register to the intended reader and purpose.
Express personal opinions, arguments, and abstract ideas with clarity, precision, depth, supporting evidence, and an awareness and refutation of counter-arguments.
Use a rich, varied, and precise vocabulary accurately and appropriately, including idiomatic expressions, collocations, and figurative language.
Demonstrate consistent and sophisticated grammatical control of complex language; errors are rare, minor, and self-corrected almost unconsciously.
cultural_competence_topics: In-depth, critical understanding and appreciation of diverse aspects of English-speaking cultures (e.g., UK, US, Canada, Australia, etc.), including their history, societal structures, political systems, values, beliefs, humor, and contemporary issues.

Ability to navigate complex and nuanced social, academic, and professional situations in English-speaking contexts with cultural sensitivity, astuteness, and appropriateness, adapting behavior and communication style as needed.
Deep appreciation and critical understanding of English literature, arts, philosophy, and intellectual traditions, including their historical, social, and cultural contexts.
Understanding of sub-cultures, regional variations, social diversity, class distinctions, and evolving cultural trends within English-speaking societies.
Ability to interpret subtle cultural cues, unspoken rules, humor, irony, sarcasm, and various registers in diverse contexts.
Awareness of potential cultural misunderstandings and sophisticated strategies for addressing them or mediating across cultures.
learning_strategies_suggestions: Engage critically and analytically with a wide range of authentic and complex English-language media, literature, academic texts, and professional documents, including texts with challenging or specialized content.
Actively participate in high-level academic, professional, or specialized activities and discussions conducted in English, aiming for leadership or significant contribution.
Seek opportunities for deep immersion and high-level interaction with educated native speakers in diverse and demanding contexts, including professional networking and collaboration.
Focus on refining stylistic choices, rhetorical effectiveness, precision in language use, and the ability to convey subtle nuances of meaning and tone.
Undertake independent research, complex projects, or creative writing in English on topics of personal or professional interest, aiming for publishable or presentable quality.
Provide mentorship or guidance to other learners of English, or engage in language teaching or tutoring if interested, thereby reinforcing and deepening one's own understanding.
Continuously reflect on and analyze language use (one's own and others') to identify areas for further refinement and to appreciate the power and subtlety of language.

learning_outcomes: Can understand with ease virtually everything heard or read.
Can summarise information from different spoken and written sources, reconstructing arguments and accounts in a coherent presentation.
Can express him/herself spontaneously, very fluently and precisely, differentiating finer shades of meaning even in more complex situations.

Full control over stylistic, pragmatic, and sociolinguistic aspects of the language, including subtle variations in register, tone, politeness, and persuasive effect across all contexts.
Ability to manipulate language creatively, effectively, and for humorous, ironic, or other sophisticated rhetorical effects, including puns and wordplay.
Deep understanding and natural, flexible use of highly idiomatic, colloquial, and culturally-specific language with native-like proficiency and appropriateness.

Awareness and potential use of historical evolution of the English language and regional/social variations in grammar and usage for specific effects or characterization (e.g., in creative writing, performance).
Sophisticated understanding of advanced linguistic concepts as applied to English (e.g., discourse analysis, pragmatics, semantics, stylistics, sociolinguistics).
Mastery of complex punctuation for clarity, nuance, and stylistic effect, including less common conventions.
vocabulary_topics: Extensive, precise, and nuanced vocabulary, including very specific, technical, literary, academic, and archaic terms across a virtually unlimited range of domains and specialized fields.
Full command of idiomatic expressions, proverbs, sayings, and cultural allusions, used appropriately, naturally, and often creatively to enrich communication.
Ability to understand, use, and even coin neologisms and slang appropriately within different social contexts, understanding their connotations, lifespan, and social implications.
Precise differentiation of synonyms, near-synonyms, and antonyms, understanding subtle connotations, collocations, and register constraints, and selecting the mot juste.
Deep understanding of etymology, word formation processes (including less common ones like back-formation or blending), and semantic relationships in English.
Vocabulary for discussing abstract, philosophical, scientific, and highly specialized topics with expert precision, eloquence, and authority.
Understanding and effective use of figures of speech, rhetorical devices, and literary terminology.

Any accent is purely personal and does not hinder intelligibility or appropriateness.
Ability to vary accent or style for specific effects, for characterization (e.g., in acting or storytelling), or to enhance communication with diverse audiences.
Mastery of all prosodic features (pitch range, volume, tempo, tone of voice) to convey meaning, emotion, attitude, and subtle nuances with precision, naturalness, and impact.
Effortless handling of connected speech phenomena (assimilation, elision, linking, weak forms) even in rapid, informal, or challenging speaking conditions.
Ability to understand and be understood by speakers of a very wide range of English accents, including those that are heavily regional or non-native.
listening_comprehension_skills: Have no difficulty in understanding any kind of spoken language, whether live or broadcast, even when delivered at fast native speed, including speech with heavy background noise, unclear articulation, overlapping speakers, regional accents, or highly colloquial/idiomatic language (given minimal or no acclimatization).
Understand implicit meanings, attitudes, irony, humor, sarcasm, and emotional undertones in all forms of spoken discourse with ease and accuracy.
Follow highly colloquial conversations, rapid-fire debates, complex group interactions, and technically dense or abstract discussions effortlessly, grasping all nuances.
Appreciate stylistic variations, rhetorical strategies, and the effective use of prosody in all types of spoken English.
reading_comprehension_skills: Read with ease and full, nuanced comprehension virtually all forms of the written language, including abstract, structurally or linguistically complex texts such as dense academic research, legal documents, specialized technical manuals, and literary works from various periods and genres (including classical, experimental, and highly contemporary).

Express oneself spontaneously, very fluently, and precisely, differentiating finer shades of meaning even in the most complex, sensitive, abstract, or unfamiliar situations and topics, often with elegance and wit.

If he/she does encounter a rare linguistic problem or search for an elusive expression, backtrack and restructure around the difficulty so smoothly, rapidly, and effectively that other people are hardly aware of it.

Mediate effectively, diplomatically, and persuasively in complex or sensitive discussions, negotiations, or conflicts, whether between native speakers or across language/cultural divides, demonstrating strong interpersonal and intercultural skills.

Adapt register and style with complete flexibility and subtlety to suit any audience, context, or communicative purpose.
spoken_production_skills: Present a clear, smoothly-flowing, well-structured, engaging, and often memorable description, argument, or narrative on any topic, in a style appropriate to the context and purpose, with an effective and sophisticated logical structure which helps the recipient to notice, understand, and remember significant points effortlessly.

Speak with the fluency, accuracy, sophistication, lexical richness, and stylistic range of a highly articulate and educated native speaker on any topic, whether concrete or abstract, familiar or unfamiliar.

Adapt speech flexibly, spontaneously, and effectively to different audiences, purposes, and situations, using a full repertoire of linguistic, rhetorical, and prosodic resources to achieve maximum impact.
Use humor, irony, storytelling, and other rhetorical devices masterfully and appropriately to achieve specific communicative effects and engage the audience.
Deliver compelling, persuasive, and memorable public speeches, lectures, or presentations with little or no preparation if necessary.
written_interaction_skills: Write any type of correspondence (formal, informal, professional, academic, personal, creative) with full command of language, style, register, tone, and persuasive techniques, achieving specific communicative goals effectively, efficiently, and often elegantly.

Craft written responses that are not only accurate, appropriate, and comprehensive but also engaging, impactful, and demonstrate critical thinking.
written_production_skills: Write clear, smoothly-flowing, sophisticated, and stylistically accomplished text in an appropriate style for a wide variety of demanding purposes (e.g., publishable academic papers, complex professional reports, policy documents, literary essays, creative writing, impactful speeches).

Write complex letters, reports, or articles which present a case with an effective logical structure, compelling arguments, nuanced analysis, sophisticated synthesis of information, and appropriate evidence, helping the recipient to understand complex issues and remember significant points.
Write insightful summaries, critical reviews, or syntheses of professional, academic, or literary works, demonstrating deep understanding, critical engagement, and original thought.

Produce creative writing of high literary quality (e.g., short stories, poetry, scripts), demonstrating mastery of narrative techniques, character development, stylistic devices, and linguistic creativity.

Employ a very wide, precise, and nuanced lexical repertoire including idiomatic, colloquial, archaic, and specialized items; show full awareness of connotative levels of meaning and use them effectively.
Maintain consistent and virtually flawless grammatical control of complex language; any errors are exceptional, non-systematic, and self-corrected immediately and unobtrusively.
cultural_competence_topics: Native-like, nuanced, and critical understanding and appreciation of all aspects of diverse English-speaking cultures, including their history, societal structures, political systems, values, beliefs, humor, irony, and contemporary issues.

Ability to function effortlessly, appropriately, and effectively in any English-speaking social, academic, or professional context, demonstrating high levels of intercultural competence and adaptability.
Deep understanding of cultural subtexts, implicit meanings, unspoken rules, sociolinguistic conventions, and power dynamics in various English-speaking societies.
Ability to discuss, analyze, and critique cultural phenomena with insight, sophistication, originality, and an awareness of multiple complex perspectives.
Understanding of the role of English as a global lingua franca, its historical impact, and its ongoing evolution and variations worldwide.
Ability to act as a cultural mediator or interpreter when needed.
